Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to study the acousto-electrical interaction in ZnO/GaN heterostructures and develop the tunable devices which comprise of a piezoelectric ZnO layer and a polar semiconductor ZnO/GaN heterostructure. The approaches include: (i) grow the polar ZnO/GaN heterostructure on c-plane sapphire using MOCVD and control its polarity through interface engineering during the heteroepitaxy; and (ii) integrate a piezoelectric ZnO film with the semiconductor ZnO/GaN heterostructure to form novel ZnO/GaN acousto-electronic devices, study and simulate its characteristics, including dispersion and multi-mode surface acoustic wave properties, conduction band offset and sheet electron concentration by considering both spontaneous and piezoelectric polarizations at the ZnO/GaN interface.
Intellectual merit: The novel ZnO/GaN acousto-electronic device possesses advantages including high acoustic velocity and large electro-mechanical coupling coefficient over a broad frequency range, high operation frequency using higher order wave modes, large tunability at low biasing voltage, the ability to perform versatile functions, and low manufacturing cost.
Broader impact: Integration of multifunctional ZnO with semiconductor GaN will promote a new level of material integration and devices technologies; therefore, open up new research opportunities and applications. The integration of research and education is an important focus of this project. The students will gain interdisciplinary knowledge base in material growth, interface physics, comprehensive characterizations, device design and simulation, and fabrication process. The research will be facilitated by strong collaboration with industrial partners. The educational outreach efforts are directed at NJ high school students, through the Governor's School, Rutgers Science Bus program, and special summer program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Project Outcomes Based on Intellectual Merit

        GaN has recently been developed into a primary wide bandgap semiconductor for new solid state lighting industry and for RF electronics. ZnO is emerging as a promising wide band gap oxide semiconductor and has been recognized as an important multifunctional material. The combination of multifunctional ZnO films on semiconductor GaN forms the ZnO/GaN heterostructures, which possess many interesting properties. The main objective of this research project is to construct a new multilayer structure consisting of a piezoelectric ZnO layer and a polar semiconductor ZnO/GaN heterostructure. Such a structure possesses the novel multi-phenomena, including tunable acousto-electronic, acousto-optic, and acousto-opto-electronic interactions.  Understanding of the interface electronic properties is critical for designing the novel devices for broad and important applications.  The acousto-electrical interaction in the structure is studied and then used to design and develop the tunable RF devices.  This project’s outcomes have promoted a new level of material integration and devices technologies. The project combines the basic studies with the transformative research with the emphasis on innovation and invention. For the duration of the grant, we were able to achieve the following major outcomes:          

        (1) Grow a new heterostructure ZnO/GaNby metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD), study and control its electronic properties, including sheet carrier accumulation and depletion in the heterojunction.

        (2) Integrated a piezoelectric ZnO film with the semiconductor ZnO/GaN heterostructure using our novel hybrid deposition technology. Investigated and simulated the electronic properties and surface acoustic wave (SAW) characteristics, designed and demonstrated the new devices with unique tunability by using acousto-electrical interaction.

        (3) For the first time, demonstrated a novel tunable SAW device in the ZnO/GaN heterostructure. The novel device operating at high frequency (1.2Ghz) demonstrates unprecedentedly high tunability (~1% frequency change, which is the best result among the existing tunable devices reported in the literature) at low biasing voltage range (<15V).The novel tunable SAW devices enable to serve as the basic building block for  broad applications, including tunable and programmable wireless sensors for commercial applications and homeland defense. Its unique tunable and multifunctional capability can be used to form the self-contained, field-deployable wireless and low-power sensors for rapid on-site diagnosis, as well as for real-time environmental monitoring. The devices can also be used for adaptive signal processing and wireless and secure communications.
